thread.title: Stanley Develops 'Road Surface-illuminated Signal Lamp'

title: Stanley Develops 'Road Surface-illuminated Signal Lamp'
text:
The mechanism of the road surface-illuminated signal lamp [Click to enlarge image] 
Stanley Electric Co Ltd developed a "road surface-illuminated signal lamp," which indicates the next movement of the vehicle for other vehicles and pedestrians. 
Combined with stop lamps and winkers, it flashes and moves light to alert others. The company aims to commercialize the lamp in 2019. 
At Ceatec Japan 2015, which runs from Oct 7 to 10, 2015, in Chiba Prefecture, Japan, Stanley introduced three functions of the lamp. They are (1) an emergency braking indicator, (2) reversing indicator and (3) turn signal. 
Emergency braking indicator 
The emergency braking indicator is for notifying following vehicles of an emergency braking. When the driver of the vehicle suddenly applies the brakes, it blinks a red pattern on the road surface. 
The pattern extends to adjacent lanes so that it can be seen by two following vehicles (not only the one right behind), Stanley said. To indicate an emergent situation, the pattern blinks on and off at a relatively high frequency of 5Hz. 
Reversing indicator 
The reversing indicator is used when the vehicle is moving backward. This function is expected to be used mainly at parking lots. It casts a white arrow-shaped striped pattern so that the direction of the vehicle's movement can be intuitively understood. 
According to Stanley, striped patterns instantly draw people's attention like crosswalks. The pattern blinks on and off at a frequency of 0.7Hz. 
Turn signal 
The turn signal indicates direction changes and right and left turns. In conjunction with winkers, it continually emits orange light so that the drivers of other vehicles notice it. It blinks at a frequency of 1.5Hz. 
The road surface-illuminated signal lamp takes in LED light, concentrates it at slits and forms a desired pattern. Then, the light is emitted to a road surface by using a projection lens.
